newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Caracas stocks succumb to 2nd day of profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: Caracas stocks succumb to 2nd day of profit-taking.

text.p: Caracas stocks closed mixed, succumbing to a second consecutive day of profit-taking after the ten percent run-up over the past two weeks, but traders saw stocks returning to an upward swing next week.

"Today's pattern was much like yesterday's, except the stocks rotated: some fell to profit-taking, others saw investors taking positions," said Amerival broker Gabriel Osio who saw the adjustment as a healthy correction after two weeks' gains.
The market's 19-share index closed largely flat, slipping 0.04 percent to end at 4,573.31.
Eleven million shares traded, to a total value of 1.2 billion bolivars ($2.55 million). Among traded issues, 15 rose, 12 fell and 10 ended unchanged.

The adjustment over, analysts see stocks rebounding next week, triggered by the slated privatizations of airline Aeropostal and key bank Banco de Venezuela. A rebound is seen despite the likelihood of another modest uptick in TEM rates.
"Barring a surprise on the privatization front, we look for the IBC rally to resume next week," said New York-based IDEA in a market commentary.
